subject: RE: [junit] re - assert counting
msgSnippet: Another problem with assertion counting is how would you count the calls to fail() which is just another form of assert?  If a test looked like this: public
messageBody:
Another problem with assertion counting is how would you count the calls to
fail() which is just another form of assert? If a test looked like this:

public void testAssertCounting() throws Exception {
if (false) {
fail();
}
}

By counting asserts it would dissuade people from using the fail method
since those wouldn't be counted. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it
should be taken into consideration.

-shane

> Interesting. But in my case I would have a lot of "false
> warnings" because I
> have a lot of methods that validate something and throw if
> it's invalid (but
> do nothing if valid, so return is void). The tests look like that :
>
> public void testAValidationTest() throws Exception {
> validator.validate(VALID_DATA);
> }
>
> So, no asserts, but a perfectly valid test case.
>
> I would then probably get 200 warnings, so how could I
> differentiate the
> legitimate ones from false ones?
>
> If this feature goes in, it should be possible to turn it on/off, like
> assert counting I guess :)

> mathieu
